► Sensor Used: Magnetometer (Magnetic Field Sensor)

 ► How it works: Detects changes in Earth's magnetic field caused by metal objects. When metal is nearby, it distorts the natural magnetic field, creating detectable variations.

 ► Simple Mode: Shows deviation from baseline magnetic field. Values above 10 µT indicate potential metal presence. Automatically calibrates to local environment.

 ► Advanced Mode: Displays raw magnetic field strength (25-65 µT typical). Useful for analyzing magnetic interference and environmental conditions.

 ► Detection Range: Effective for large metal objects within 5-15cm. Smaller objects like coins detectable within 2-5cm. Range varies by phone model.

 ► Earth's Magnetic Field: Natural strength ranges from 25-65 µTesla depending on location. Stronger at poles, weaker at equator.

 ► Accuracy Tips: Calibrate away from metal surfaces, move slowly, keep phone flat, avoid electronic interference (WiFi/Bluetooth).

 ► Safety Note: This is not a professional metal detector. Do not rely on it for safety-critical applications or treasure hunting.

 ► Fun Fact: Your phone's magnetometer is the same technology used in navigation compasses and professional geological surveys!

► Sensor Used: Gravity Sensor (Software-based)

 ► How it works: Uses accelerometer data with filtering to isolate gravitational force from motion. Combines hardware readings with smart algorithms to separate gravity from device movement.

 ► Earth's Gravity: Standard gravity is 9.8 m/s² downward. Actual values vary slightly by location due to altitude, latitude, and local geology.

 ► Vector Display: Shows gravity components on X, Y, Z axes. The arrow points in the direction gravity is pulling relative to your device orientation.

 ► Real-time Graph: Tracks gravity changes over time. Useful for analyzing device movement patterns and orientation stability.

 ► Device Orientation: Automatically detects phone position - horizontal, vertical, facing up/down. Based on which axis has the strongest gravity component.

 ► Magnitude Calculation: Total gravity = √(X² + Y² + Z²). Should be close to 9.8 m/s² when device is stationary.

 ► Applications: Used in navigation, gaming, screen rotation, and scientific measurements. Essential for augmented reality and motion sensing.

 ► Fun Fact: This sensor fusion technology enables your phone to know its orientation in 3D space, powering features from auto-rotate to fitness tracking!

► Sensors Used: Accelerometer + Magnetometer (Fusion Sensor)

 ► How it works: Combines accelerometer and magnetometer data to calculate precise device orientation using rotation matrix.

 ► Pitch (Y-axis): Forward/backward tilt - like tilting your phone toward or away from you. Positive = tilted up, Negative = tilted down.

 ► Roll (X-axis): Left/right tilt - like rotating your phone clockwise or counterclockwise. Positive = tilted right, Negative = tilted left.

 ► Level Detection: When both pitch and roll are within tolerance range (±0.5° to ±5°), the bubble turns green and haptic feedback triggers.

 ► Features: Multiple sensitivity modes, haptic feedback, and real-time bubble physics simulation.

 ► Professional Use: Perfect for construction, carpentry, picture hanging, and any leveling task requiring precision.

 ► Fun Fact: Uses the same sensor fusion technology found in professional digital levels costing hundreds of dollars!
